etymologies: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Thomas Blount (1618–1679), antiquary and lexicographer. From classical Latin dulcis sweet + -loquent, after classical Latin dulciloquus (2nd century a.d. in Apuleius)

definitions: Of a person: sweet-spoken. Hence also of an utterance, style, etc.: characterized by pleasing or mellifluous language.
